intro: Mitracarpus polycladus, commonly known as the Indian mallow, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia. It is characterized by its large, palmate leaves and showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is known for its hairy stems and lobed foliage. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or along riverbanks. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it can become invasive in certain environments.
